DOC.HEAD: Lithuania's Communists Urge United Political Front
With AM-Soviet-Congress, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's Communist Party leader Tuesday urged a united political front with other parties to press for sovereignty and protect the Baltic republic from Kremlin pressure. Algirdas Brazauskas, in an address to more than 1,000 delegates at the opening session of the Lithuanian Communist Party Congress, avoided calling for an immediate, direct break with the Soviet Communist Party or for Lithuanian indepenence. But he left open both possibilities. Lithuania, he said, saw itself as part a union of Soviet republics undergoing a radical transformation under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms that ``will allow us to build a Soviet Union from which we can secede if we wanted to.'' Gorbachev has spoken out against plans to split the Lithuanian party from the national Communist Party and to restore the independent Lithuanian state that existed between the World Wars. But the Lithuanians have continued to press for more autonomy, and an initial step Dec. 7 removed constitutional language that made the Communist Party the leading force in society. The national Congress of People's Deputies last week refused to discuss such a move, but Communist parties in Eastern Europe already have given up that special status as change sweeps the region. Brazauskas told the delegates in a nearly 1{-hour speech: ``Only with an independent Communist Party is it possible to compete normally and on an equal footing with oher political forces.'' ``Political power is achieved only through democratic elections,'' he added. Romas Gudaitis, a Lithuanian writer, said separation was justified because ``the Soviet Commuinist Party is still mired in Stalinism.'' Brazauskas said the Lithuanian party, freed from its subordination to Moscow, was prepared to cooperate with the powerful political movement Sajudis and other parties in a ``united front'' to govern the republic of 3.7 million people. ``Practically all parties in Lithuania today proclaim the same, or practically the same, goals,'' he said. Those newly formed parties include the Social Democrats and a party advocating outright independence from the Soviet Union. ``A united front, if it became truly united and consolidated Lithuania, would be a good counterbalance to any attempts from outside to restrict our achievments,'' he said in an obvious reference to fears that Moscow might try to limit Lithuania's drive for sovereignty. Progressive Communist leaders in Lithuania and the other Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia, are already closely identified with Sajudis and other people's fronts organizations, but Brazauskas' proposal was to extend and formalize that relationship, apparently to make the Communist Party a coalition partner. Arvydas Juozaitis, a member of the Sajudis governing council, told reporters that Sajudis was not interested in a united front. ``I'm not sure they are absolutely acceptable to us under this name,'' he said. The Communist Party, regardless of what decision it makes at this week's congress, is nearly dead, he said. ``They are reburying a dead body in another grave, from a Soviet grave to a national grave,'' he said. Juozaitis added, however, that it was ``very possible'' the Lithuanian Communist Party would soon change its name. Lithuanian leaders have said they needed to compete in Feb. 24 local elections and that requires them to develop a program independent of Moscow. Many local Communist leaders in March were beaten badly in elections to the national Congress of People's Deputies because they were too closely identified with decades of Moscow's heavy-handed policies. Although the party's proposed rules do not mention any firm relationship with the Soviet party, Brazauskas vowed their would be no immediate break with it. ``The declaration and legitimization of the statutes of the independent Lithuanian Communist Party does not mean breaking off the relationship with the Soviet Communist, but reshaping it and (making) a transition from subordination to partnership,'' the party said in a draft document. Outside, hundreds of people gathered on the steps of the opera and ballet theater where the Congress was being held. They carried red, green and yellow Lithuanian flags and banners backing the party's proposed independence from Moscow. A small group of demonstrators marched down Gediminas Avenue, the main street, to protest even a reformed Communist Party. One sign proclaimed, ``Stop Communism in Lithuania,'' with the word ``Communism'' painted red to simulate dripping blood. The Congress is to last most of the week and observers expect a vote on the party's status to take place Wednesday or Thursday. Juozaitis said he thought Latvia, Estonia, Georgia and Armenia soon might follow the lead of the Lithuanian party in separating from the national organization, strengthening Lithuania's hand in dealing with Gorbachev.
